1 Kinetic Energy, Power, and the Work-Energy Theorem

1.1 Kinetic Energy and Power

Definition 1.1.

Definition 1.2.

1.2 The Work-Energy Theorem

We can relate Pyâ¢w/a to kinetic energy as follows. Taking the time-derivative of Tyâ¢w/a=12â¢myâ¢vâ†’yâ¢w/aâ‹…vâ†’yâ¢w/a and assuming that my is constant results in

Fact 1.1.

The following time derivative property holds for any physical vector uâ†’.

ddâ¢tâ¢(uâ†’â‹…uâ†’)=uâ†’âˆ™iâ‹…uâ†’+uâ†’â‹…uâ†’âˆ™i=2â¢uâ†’âˆ™iâ‹…uâ†’,

uâ†’âˆ™aâ‹…uâ†’ =(uâ†’âˆ™b+Ï‰â†’bâ¢aÃ—uâ†’)â‹…uâ†’
=uâ†’âˆ™bâ‹…uâ†’+(Ï‰â†’bâ¢aÃ—uâ†’)â‹…uâ†’.

Using the fact that Ï‰â†’bâ¢aÃ—uâ†’=âˆ’uâ†’Ã—Ï‰â†’bâ¢a and resolving the physical vectors uâ†’ and Ï‰â†’bâ¢a in an arbitrary reference frame â„±i, we can show that

uâ†’âˆ™aâ‹…uâ†’ =uâ†’âˆ™bâ‹…uâ†’âˆ’(uâ†’Ã—Ï‰â†’bâ¢a)â‹…uâ†’

which demonstrates that uâ†’âˆ™aâ‹…uâ†’=uâ†’âˆ™bâ‹…uâ†’ and thus, the computation uâ†’âˆ™iâ‹…uâ†’ is the same for any reference frame â„±i.

Returning to the derivative of kinetic energy inÂ (1), we can apply FactÂ 1.1 to yield

ddâ¢tâ¢(Tyâ¢w/a) =12â¢myâ¢ddâ¢tâ¢(vâ†’yâ¢w/aâ‹…vâ†’yâ¢w/a)

If we choose â„±a to be an inertial frame, w to be an unforced particle, and my to be constant, then Newtonâ€™s 2nd Law dictates that

myâ¢aâ†’yâ¢w/a/a=fâ†’y, (3)

where fâ†’y is the force acting on particle y. SubstitutingÂ (3) intoÂ (2) results in

ddâ¢tâ¢(Tyâ¢w/a)=fâ†’yâ‹…vâ†’yâ¢w/a=Pyâ¢w/aâ¢(fâ†’y). (4)

Eq.Â (4) is known as the Work-Energy Theorem. Note that Eq.Â (4) is only valid if w is an unforced particle and â„±a is an inertial reference frame.

The Work-Energy Theorem is valid for any force (conservative or non-conservative) acting on particle y. Reaction forces do not need to be considered, since there is no motion in their direction and they would disappear when taking the dot product with vâ†’yâ¢w/a.

1.3 The 4 Alternative Steps to Success in Dynamics

We can use the Work-Energy Theorem as an alternative approach to derive the equation of motion of a single degree-of-freedom particle. This method is a stepping stone towards a Lagrangian approach to dynamics, which is covered in graduate-level dynamics courses (also in Section 5 of the Forbes notes).

The 4 alternative steps to success in dynamics are

  1. 1.

    Kinematics

    1. i)

      Frames and DCMs

    2. ii)

      Angular Velocity

    3. iii)

      Position

    4. iv)

      Velocity

  2. 2.

    Kinetic Energy

  3. 3.

    Forces

  4. 4.

    Work-Energy Theorem

Example 1.1.
